42 percent of U.S. COVID-19 deaths have occurred in nursing homes and assisted living facilities!! https://t.co/fxFqXHyySZ

THERE WERE 1135 REGULATIONS TO WAIVE?
I don't think I could even make up 1135. 

"In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, numerous regulatory policies and 1135 waivers of federal requirements have been implemented by CMS" https://t.co/K9TH9stiPy
Frailty in the Face of COVID-19 https://t.co/iSewZkgCdH

I have to say in light of Covid-19 societal changes, it has been really wonderful, terrifying, and humbling to see the profound impact that older adults and the elderly have on everyone's lives. 

Everyone has an older adult they care about, 
worry about, 
and love.

#geriatrics
@ARadDocDates Shaved coconut. Don't know if it's the texture or the taste but I just can't
@tanyawildes This experience has taught me sooo much that I hope I can share with patients with altered taste and smell!
@IAprahamian It hasn't actually. It's about 40-50% back I would say. Taste has come back faster then smell
@anita_turk 5 long loooong weeks. i'm feeling good, smell and taste are inching back. Just eager to see patients again
@Guifa9 Mostly, a little tired still.. No smell or taste is the primary symptom at this point
@crdangelo9 Oh my gosh would you believe they are just sweet and sort of chewy without ANY TASTE DISTINCTION? It's like the green and red ones aren't the best anymore.

GUYS I CAN KIND OF TASTE MAGGI SEASONING

#anosmia

Note to self: If someone says they can't taste anything encouraging them to eat doesn't help. 

I have tried eating: soap, salt, honey, chocolate, orange peels, onion, raw garlic, ice cream. It all tastes like nothing.

@nancy_kistner I honestly don't think so. Obviously I'm not an ID specialist in this field. FWIW I tested negative formally after about 5 weeks but smell has not recovered. My best guess is the cells that were lost in the healing just need time to come back. Best of luck to your daughter!
@IAprahamian It hasn't actually. It's about 40-50% back I would say. Taste has come back faster then smell
@anita_turk 5 long loooong weeks. i'm feeling good, smell and taste are inching back. Just eager to see patients again
@Guifa9 Mostly, a little tired still.. No smell or taste is the primary symptom at this point
@jack_turban Makes me nervous about going in for my follow up swab. I still can't smell but otherwise totally asymptomatic.
@heligamoder Nope, it's maybe 10% back? I can sort of smell some stronger scents like a hand soap or coffee a little.

I think I'm starting to regain my sense of smell a tad! Coffee was not just bitter water today!

Chocolate is still mostly tasteless though. üç´üò≠

@Bond_Jacob Definitely. The timeline of fevers and aches a few days after seeing a Pt who later tested positive for covid was pretty classic. I was surprised the first test was negative but mild sx, so I believed it. But when I lost my sense of smell I knew I had to get retested.

Adventures with #anosmia. 

I burned my food because you don't smell the food burning, things just get mysteriously smoky and suddenly you're coughing more.

@ZacharySagerMD it was last and to be fair it was more like I licked a bar of soap. 

I have also inhaled hand soap because I was trying to smell it and nothing happened ü§£

3) Foods with 'other' strong triggers. Banana is relatively ok, I think because the texture was so characteristic. Spicy food. Eggs. All have some other cue to trick my brain.

With complete anosmia how matter how fragrant, it has no taste. Onion, garlic, etc.

@LPerrytheGeriMD @laxswamy @chandan_khandai @ShikhaJainMD @danielalamasmd @RanaAwdish @Potato_Chip @sickgirlspeaks @AG_EM33 @iwashyna @drjessigold @icurehab @DrDaleNeedham @Dr_Ridge_DPT @LeilaniRGraham @BUgeriatrics @sharon_inouye @Megany221 @DrAROrkaby @SusanNathan13 @EWidera @LouiseAronson @drmrsapoth @wassdoc Call family in the pt room to update and make sure they talk to pt. Family reminding them of the progress they made is so so important. 

Also anosmia is a real appetite killer so watch weights and provide nutritious meals, possibly with lots of salt. Like, allll the salt.
@MSK_GeriOnc Getting there!!! Anosmia is sloooooooowly improving.
@HshiehTammy Almost 3weeks now. But anosmia has been about two weeks

@LiskClifford Not sure, persistent anosmia and positive testing is still anecdotal. But if there is a situation where testing is not readily available, it might be better to err on the conservative side.

Just had my first retest and I'm still #covid positive. Pretty stunned because apart from #anosmia I'm feeling 90% back to normal. But it seems to be that as long as anosmia persists, people continue to be positive.

So it's official. 

I tested positive for COVID. As a nursing home provider it pains me that I cant be there to help my patients, but I know this would hurt them more than me.

FWIW I was tested last week, and it was neg. I got retested when anosmia developed. And here I am

@LPerrytheGeriMD yeah, the myalgias are pretty much gone so it's mostly just a little fatigue and of course my good friend anosmia.
